Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is in allowing property owners to fully develop their land for economic benefit, while satisfying regulatory requirements and, at the same time, protecting the water resources that we rely on for water supply, environmental benefits and recreation. Currently, land owners use developable land to manage storm water. This project will consider how to best use the soil throughout the site to manage the storm water and free up more of the site for development. By spreading out runoff that naturally concentrates when we construct buildings, roads and parking lots more water can soak into the ground. With this infiltration, pollutants picked up on the land surface can be removed by the soil rather than flowing directly to a stream. Infiltrated water moves underground to streams and provides the continuous stream flow needed by wildlife. Distributing runoff to the soil surrounding our buildings and pavement can also help keep runoff out of the combined storm and sanitary sewers found in many older communities, allowing the aging infrastructure to continue to function and reducing the combined sewer overflows.

This I-Corps project will result in a new solution, transforming the way storm water runoff is managed; improving water quality and maintaining stream baseflow required by wildlife, while decreasing costs and requiring less space to meet permitting requirements. The solution consists of devices that are specially constructed to slow down the flow of water and redirect it in a way that allows it to seep into the surrounding soil. The core technology is based upon the well-established principle that the size, mix and way materials are arranged determines the way liquids flow. A patent for the solution has been issued because of the new, innovative way of constructing and deploying these simple materials (i.e., sand and gravel placed in tubes of the geotextile fabric often used in landscaping), allowing water to be directed in three dimensions. Concentrated runoff, for example the accelerated flow of water off a parking lot, that is intercepted by the device, is first slowed and then directed down into the soil or is moved left or right to the next device segment.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project is to explore the commercial opportunity for the technology described in Patent Number US009255393, Storm Water Redistribution Device being developed and commercialized by Infiltronics Environmental LLC.

Need

To determine if there was a need for additional stormwater management methods two questions needed to be answered: (1) does stormwater have to be managed and (2) are the current solutions satisfactory? The first is answered through regulatory requirements in the Clean Water Act (CWA) and the implementing regulations, requiring management of stormwater runoff after development. By conducting 191 interviews over the past 1.5 years with engineers, regulators, property developers, installers, and other stormwater management technology companies, we determined that although regulators are approving plans and developers and engineers are implementing management methods, neither party is entirely satisfied with the current solutions. The regulators realize that engineers often do the best they can do with the options available while being fiscally responsible, but the solutions are not producing the results they would like to see in terms of real impact on stormwater runoff quality and quantity. Meanwhile, engineers and developers want a solution that allows for maximum land development and minimum cost, a balance that is not easily struck. We also learned about other aspects a stormwater best management practice (BMP) needs to provide in order to be a complete solution: easy maintenance, straightforward installation and design, efficient use of space, and to be at least somewhat aesthetically pleasing. This showed us that the second aspect of our product?s market opportunity is validated as well.

Customer

From the interviews conducted information on the pains and needs of the customer and who the customer is were determined. The market is two-sided and the two customers are the land developer who pays for the physical device and the consulting civil engineer who works on behalf of the developer to get the development plans approved. The engineer will specify and sign off on the stormwater management method they believe will best meet the regulatory requirement and project constrains. The developer wants a solution that will allow them to develop as much land as possible and will result in the greatest project cost possible. The engineer wants a solution that will meet regulatory requirements and can be designed and installed in a straightforward manner. In short, product-market fit was found when we learned who the customer was, what their problem was, and that the benefits we believe our technology can produce solve their problem.

Regulatory Environment

The regulatory framework for stormwater in the United States is far from uniform. The federal mandate is applied in each state at a minimum, but each state, county, and municipality interprets it and puts it into practice in their own way. Some choose to make specific additions and increases to regulatory requirements based upon regional challenges or desire for a higher management standard. We learned that the real key factor for adoption is providing data and case studies to engineers and regulators to show them how the system works and that it does indeed work. Often regulators will negotiate on and accept a unique stormwater installation from a consulting engineer based upon his or her calculations and credibility, with the understanding that if something fails it will be the owner?s and engineer?s responsibility to mitigate any adverse effects and replace the failed solution.  

Market 

Those developing land must construct and maintain stormwater BMPs on their property in accordance with the CWA and implementing state and local regulations in communities of at least 10,000 people and developments of at least one acre. We will initially launch our product in one or two regions in the US where we have identified the ideal combination of characteristics, of population density, strict local/regional regulations, and easy access to raw materials.  Starting in just one or two regions will help insure that we are not spreading ourselves too thinly. One possible starting region is California, which has our ideal characteristics, including a stormwater management hierarchy in metropolitan areas with infiltration second only to capture and reuse. A market analysis was conducted to determine if the market would be viable. The revenue potential of the land development industry in the US in 2017 was $11.4B, assuming that on a given project 25% of the project cost can go towards stormwater management, as stated in interviews by consulting civil engineers, the total available market (TAM) would be $2.85B/year. If we assume that California?s GDP percentage of the US GDP, 13.5%, can be related to their percentage of land development, we get a served available market (SAM) of $390M/year. If we then look at the percentage of Californians who live in a community of over 10,000 people, 63%, we can calculate our target market for one year in California as $245.7M. 


Last Modified: 05/04/2019
Modified by: Kathleen M Trauth
